title: 114_s1885
content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of a homeless veteran for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. This involves amending a specific section of the United States Code related to the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of a homeless veteran for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, including a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands benefits for homeless veterans by providing intensive case management interventions through a program required by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Covered veterans must be enrolled in the homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" mandates a program operated by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs at six selected locations, including cities with high homeless veteran populations and suburban/rural settings. Locations must have a high degree of interaction and coordination. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" mandates a program operated by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs at selected locations with high homeless veteran populations. The program involves intensive case management interventions for covered veterans receiving health care services. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to provide intensive case management interventions to covered veterans at locations with high homeless veteran populations. This includes assistance with gaining access to housing, benefits, and services to improve stability and healthcare appropriateness. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to offer intensive case management interventions to covered veterans in areas with high homeless veteran populations. This involves aiding in accessing housing, benefits, and services to enhance stability and healthcare suitability. Additionally, chapter 20 of the title is amended to include a new item after section 2066. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to implement intensive case management interventions for covered veterans in high homeless veteran population areas by September 1, 2016. A report on the program must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by December 1, 2018, including assessments of various aspects. The report on the intensive case management program for veterans must include assessments of the types and frequencies of interventions, housing status, employment status before and after receiving interventions. The report on the intensive case management program for veterans will include the number of veterans who received interventions, their use of health care services, and related costs incurred by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The report on the intensive case management program for veterans will include the number of veterans who received interventions, their use of health care services, related costs incurred by the Department of Veterans Affairs, and the costs incurred by the Department in carrying out the program, disaggregated by provision of intensive case management interventions in specific locations. The report will estimate the costs the Department would have incurred for providing health care to covered veterans if not for intensive case management interventions, broken down by locations where interventions were provided. Program to improve retention of housing by formerly homeless veterans and veterans at risk of becoming homeless. The Secretary is required to implement a program providing case management services to help veterans retain housing after experiencing homelessness or being at risk of homelessness. The Secretary implements a program to provide grants for case management services to improve housing retention for homeless veterans transitioning to permanent housing or at risk of homelessness. Priority is given to organizations with experience in transitional housing services. The Secretary gives extra priority to organizations that voluntarily stop receiving funding for transitional housing services and convert their facilities to provide permanent housing that meets housing quality standards. The conversion of facilities funded under section 2011 grants to meet Department needs will not be considered non-compliance. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to prescribe regulations within one year to improve housing retention for homeless veterans. Additionally, a report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019. Authorization of appropriations was also mentioned in 2014. The report to be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs will include assessments of the percentage of veterans who retained permanent housing through case management services under the program. The report will include data on veterans who did not retain permanent housing at the end of the program, broken down by housing status and reasons for not retaining housing. It will also compare the use of housing assistance by veterans before and after receiving case management services. The report will assess the employment status of veterans who received case management services, comparing their status before and after receiving the services. SEC. 5. EXPANSION OF HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM OF DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to assist homeless veterans, veterans at risk of homelessness, and very low-income veteran families. The amendment to Section 2041 of title 38, United States Code, aims to assist very low-income veteran families in acquiring shelter and transitioning to permanent housing. It includes provisions for maintaining occupancy in permanent housing for veterans and families in need. The amendment aims to provide housing for homeless veterans and their families, ensuring veterans receive permanent or transitional housing. The amendment ensures veterans at the property receive referrals for entitled benefits and services. Additionally, it replaces "homeless veterans" with "veterans and families described in paragraph (1)" in clause (v). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. SEC. 6. OUTREACH RELATING TO INCREASING THE AMOUNT OF HOUSING AVAILABLE TO VETERANS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs collaborates with various entities to educate them about the housing needs of veterans and the benefits of having veterans as tenants. Additionally, a National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans is established. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs establishes the National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans to operate independently and address homelessness among veterans. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans, established by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, focuses on researching causes of veteran homelessness, evaluating program effectiveness, and sharing best practices for housing stabilization, income support, and employment assistance. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans, established by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, aims to integrate evidence-based practices for homeless veterans, serve as a resource center for research and training activities, and coordinate information exchange on veteran homelessness. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans, established by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, aims to integrate evidence-based practices for homeless veterans and coordinate information exchange on veteran homelessness. A new item is added to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title related to veteran homelessness. The National Center on Homelessness Among Veterans was established by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to integrate evidence-based practices for homeless veterans and coordinate information exchange on veteran homelessness. A new item is added to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title related to veteran homelessness, including administrative improvements to grant and per diem programs of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection (e) for the review and conditional renewal of grant recipients and eligible entities receiving per diem payments for services provided to veterans. The Secretary will evaluate their performance annually. The Secretary will annually evaluate the performance of grant recipients or eligible entities in assisting veterans with obtaining housing and increasing their income. Per diem payments will only be provided to those who meet performance criteria. The Secretary will evaluate grant recipients and eligible entities annually based on performance criteria to determine continued per diem payments. Uniform performance targets will be established for evaluation purposes.
